questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for rescue analgesia?
questions.solution:
Fentanyl is the drug of choice for rescue analgesia.

Rescue analgesia involves the use of medications to minimize postoperative pain. Mild pain can be controlled with oral analgesics, but severe pain requires opioids like fentanyl.

Fentanyl is preferred over morphine or oxycodone due to its rapid onset of action, lesser incidence of postoperative nausea, vomiting, and other adverse effects.

questions.text: Penicillin G is the drug of choice for all of the following conditions except_________.
questions.solution:
Penicillin G is not the drug of choice for Lyme disease. Penicillin G is an alternative to third-generation cephalosporins in the treatment of severe Lyme disease. 

Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks (hard ticks).

The disease occurs in 3 stages:

Primary stage - characterized by the characteristic bull’s eye rash. The rash starts as a small macule at the site of the tick bite and gradually expands with central clearing.
Secondary stage - characterized by secondary annular skin rashes, migratory arthritis, fever, and generalized lymphadenopathy. This stage can be associated with neurological abnormalities like aseptic meningitis and cranial nerve palsies. Patients may also develop myocarditis with associated AV block.
Tertiary stage - characterized by chronic arthritis, cranial nerve palsies, ataxia, and dermatitis. 
Doxycycline is the drug of choice in the initial stages of Lyme disease when there is no CNS involvement. If there is CNS involvement, i.v. ceftriaxone is used for treatment.

Options A and D: Penicillin G is the drug of choice for all forms of actinomycosis and rat-bite fever. 

Option B: Ampicillin or penicillin G is the drug of choice for Listeria infections.

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient points towards the diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. 

IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and prevention of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Synchronized cardioversion Defibrillation

Used in VT and VF with a pulse

Also used in SVT, atrial flutter/fibrillation

 Used in VT and VF without a pulse
Shock delivered in sync with R wave (in absolute refractory period) Shock delivered at any time during cardiac cycle 

Monophasic: 100-200 J

Biphasic: 50-100 J

Monophasic: 360 J

Biphasic:1 20-200 J

questions.text: Treatment of choice of ITP with mild symptoms is ___________.
questions.solution:
None of the above options are indicated in idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) with mild symptoms. 

Watchful expectancy with education and counseling of the family and patient is indicated in mild cases.

Treatment of ITP

  • Mild to moderate bleeding symptoms: watchful expectancy
  • Platelet count < 30,000 + risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders): Oral glucocorticoids/ intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or IV anti-D
  • Severe bleeding symptoms: IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG or IV anti-D
  • Life-threatening bleeding (eg. intracranial hemorrhage): platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG or IV anti-D

questions.text: Which  of  the following platinum based drugs are used in cervical cancer along with  radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is the drug of choice for chemotherapy for cervical cancer.

The primary management for cervical cancer is chemoradiation therapy. This involves the combination of external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy, and chemotherapy (usually with cisplatin). This approach has been shown to improve overall survival and reduce the risk of local and distant recurrence compared to radiation therapy alone.

Following chemoradiation, patients should be closely monitored for treatment response and potential side effects or complications. This includes regular physical examinations, Pap tests, and imaging studies as needed. The prognosis for stage IIB cervical cancer depends on various factors, such as the size of the tumor, lymph node involvement, and the patient's overall health. With appropriate treatment, the 5-year survival rate for stage IIB cervical cancer is around 58-63%.

Other Options:

Option A: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin is used in case of very aggressive recurrent tumors and residual tumors.

Option B: Trastuzumab is indicated for adjuvant therapy in early and metastatic HER2 positive breast cancer. 

Option D: Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic used for the treatment of squamous cell cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is posted for laparoscopic appendectomy. which of the following inhalational agent is preferred for induction?
questions.solution:
Induction agent of choice in pediatric anesthesia is sevoflurane.

Although both halothane and sevoflurane provide a smooth induction, sevoflurane appears to have a greater therapeutic index than halothane and is the preferred agent for inhaled induction in pediatric anesthesia.

Isoflurane and desflurane are airway irritants. Hence not used for induction of anesthesia as they can precipitate laryngospasm. These agents are used only during maintenance of anesthesia.

questions.text: A 53 years old is found to be hypertensive stage 2 without any co morbidities. Which drug will you start?
questions.solution:
Chlorthalidone is one of the first choice drugs in the treatment of hypertension without any comorbidities.
 
First-choice drugs used in the treatment of hypertension in patients without any comorbidities include:
  • Thiazide diuretics: Chlorthalidone is usually preferred to hydrochlorothiazide.
  • Calcium channel blockers: Extended-release, long-acting dihydropyridines are preferred.
  • ACE inhibitors: Captopril is preferred for the initiation of therapy. Enalapril and ramipril twice daily may also be used.
 
In the presence of any associated conditions or comorbidities, the first choice drugs for the treatment of hypertension would be as follows:
 
 
Conditions associated with hypertension
First choice drugs for hypertension
Diabetes
Chronic kidney disease with proteinuria
Inhibitors of renin-angiotensin system.
Angina
Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers
Heart failure
ACE inhibitors and alpha+beta blockers such as carvedilol
Benign prostatic hyperplasia
α1 Blockers
Pregnancy
Labetalol
Atrial fibrillation
Diltiazem and verapamil

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with hepatitis and personality changes. A picture of her eye has been provided below. Which of the following is the drug of choice for pregnant women and maintenance therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image provided above represents the Kayser-Fleischer ring which is seen in Wilson's disease. The drug of choice for maintenance therapy in this condition is Zinc.

Wilsons disease is an autosomal-recessive disease caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. It is characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomic. It does not interfere with vision. It is present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms. However, the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Neurological: Dystonia, rigidity, tremor or choreiform movements, abnormal gait due to basal ganglia (e.g., caudate, putamen) involvement.
  • Behavioural disturbancesOccular characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Sternlieb's criteria: Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

The initial treatment in symptomatic patients is the administration of copper-chelating agents, which leads to the rapid excretion of excess deposited copper.

  • D-penicillamine: It increases urinary excretion of copper and prevents copper overload. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 ) is administered along with it to counter pyridoxine deficiency that occurs due to penicillamine.
  • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride: This chelating agent is given in patients intolerant to D-penicillamine and those with severe neurologic manifestations (D-penicillamine worsens neurological status).
  • Zinc acetate: This is used due to its unique ability to impair the gastrointestinal absorption of copper. Zinc is beneficial in pregnancy (lower teratogenic effects) and as a maintenance therapy.
  • Liver transplantation: This is considered in advanced stages of irreversible hepatic damage or poor compliance to medical therapy.

Related Pearl: Intracellular accumulations

Substance accumulated Seen in

Cholesterol and cholesterol esters

Atherosclerosis

Xanthomas

Cholesterolosis

Niemann Pick disease type c
Mallory bodies(keratin filaments)

Alcoholic liver disease

Morbid obesity

Indian childhood cirrhosis

Wilson’s disease

Primary biliary cirrhosis
Lipofuscin Free radical injury
Immunoglobulins Russel bodies and Dutcher bodies of multiple myeloma
Melanin

Normal endocrine cells of the duodenal mucosa

Carcinoid syndrome

Alkaptonuria
Copper  Wilson disease
Hemosiderin Hemochromatosis

questions.text: Drug of choice for type III hyperlipoproteinemia is
questions.solution:
Fibrates are the drug of choice for patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia and those with severe hypertriglyceredemia (TG >1000 mg/dl)who are at risk for pancreatitis. 

Type III hyperlipoproteinemia patients are most sensitive responders to fibrate therapy. 

  • Elevated triglyceride and cholesterol levels are dramatically lowered.
  • Tuberoeruptive and palamr xanthomas may regress completely.
  • Angina and intermittent claudication also improve.

questions.text: The fundoscopy findings of a known case of HIV with low CD4 counts in shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts "sauce and cheese" retinopathy, which is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice.

CMV retinitis is the most probable diagnosis as the patient is immunocompromised (transplant recipient) and the fundoscopy shows patchy areas of retinal necrosis with irregular borders and overlying retinal hemorrhages.

CMV retinitis is mainly of 2 types

Central CMV retinitis

  • Dense, white areas of retinal necrosis
  • Retinal hemorrhage in the areas of necrosis
  • Pizza pie or sauce and cheese appearance

Peripheral CMV retinitis

  • Less demarcated
  • Infection spreads along the vascular arcades in a brush fire-like fashion.

The serological assay is not informative in the case of the immunocompromised patient and PCR assay is the gold standard for diagnosis.
CMV mostly causes infection in immunocompromised patients such as transplant recipients and AIDS. The most common infections are interstitial pneumonitis, gastroenteritis, esophagitis, and retinitis. Apart from ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir are approved for treatment of CMV retinitis in patients with AIDS.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with incomplete vaccination history comes with vomiting after bouts of severe, violent cough. His nasopharyngeal aspirate shows Gram negative coccobacilli. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of pertussis/whooping cough caused by Bordetella pertussis. Macrolide antibiotics are the treatment of choice.

Whooping cough derives its name from the inspiratory whoop at the end of a coughing bout. The disease courses over 3 phases after an incubation period of 2 weeks:

  • Catarrhal - lasts for 1-2 weeks and consists of cough, coryza, and nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • Paroxysmal - lasts for 2-6 weeks and consists of worsening paroxysms of productive whooping cough. It becomes more frequent and ends with vomiting. 
  • Convalescent - Intensity and frequency of cough decrease over 4 weeks.

Management :

  • Erythromycin (or Azithromycin) for 14 days 
  • Salbutamol nebulization
  • Avoid antihistamines and cough suppresants

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for her?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from rapid cycling bipolar disorder. Sodium valproate is the drug of choice for this disorder.

Diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year
  • Episodes either have a partial or full remission for atleast 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

A recent trial found that increased levels of parathyroid hormone in patients with bipolar disorder were associated with worse clinical outcomes. Researchers suggest vitamin D supplementation as a possible add on treatment.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male complains of burning sensation in both the legs and episodes of excruciating pain, tingling and a sensation he describes as "pins and needles". Which of the following is a first-line drug used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from painful diabetic neuropathy in the scenario given above. Duloxetine is a selective serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Painful diabetic neuropathy manifests as burning, excruciating, stabbing or intractable type of pain or presents with tingling or numbness. The pathophysiology of this condition is due to primarily metabolic and vascular factors.

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

 First-line:

  • Lidoderm 5% patch
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
  • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
  • Duloxetine

Second line:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Venlafaxine
  • Tramadol

Third line:

  • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The parents give a history of the child ingesting 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to iron overdose, which is managed with deferoxamine (also known as desferrioxamine).

Large amounts of ferrous salts can be fatal in children. Initial symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. In severe cases, cyanosis and hyperventilation due to metabolic acidosis can develop. This can sometimes be followed by an asymptomatic phase. Later, hypoglycemia and hepatic and renal failure can develop. Pyloric stenosis and gastric scarring can develop due to its corrosive nature. Ultimately, if left untreated, the child can die.

The gastric contents can be used for an iron color test to estimate the iron concentration in plasma. As iron tablets are radiopaque, an X-ray can be used to assess the number of pills taken. Deferoxamine, an iron chelator has to be administered intramuscularly. Side effects include pruritus, wheals, rash, and anaphylaxis. 

Deferiprone and deferasirox are other oral iron chelators used to treat iron overload in thalassemia patients. 

Other options:

Option B: Activated charcoal can be used in the initial management of acetaminophen and opioid overdose. It is used for gastrointestinal decontamination to prevent further absorption of the poison.

Option C: Dimercaprol, also known as BAL (British anti-Lewisite), is used to treat arsenic, mercury poisoning, and Wilson's disease.

Option D: D-penicillamine (Cuprimine) can be used to treat scleroderma, Wilson's disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. Side effects include nephrotoxicity, hematologic derangements, and a characteristic rash that involves the neck and axillae—elastosis perforans serpiginosa. It is associated with membranous glomerulonephritis, drug-induced lupus, and myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient complains of diarrhea, vomiting and abdominal pain that was aggravated on ingestion of food since 1 week. The stool microscopy reveals the following. The appropriate treatment for this condition would be ______
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the stool microscopy image showing the rhabditiform larva are suggestive of Strongyloidiasis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition would be Ivermectin.

Strongyloides stercoralis is a parasitic nematode known for causing chronic diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV. In this case, only larvae (and not ova) are seen in the stool, which is characteristic of Strongyloides infection due to its autoinfective cycle, where the larvae hatch inside the intestine and are passed in the stool.

Strongyloidiasis:

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

It is generally an asymptomatic condition. There may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations in some cases. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms. 

The term larva currens (meaning ‘racing larvae’) has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route. 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
Stool culture and serological tests are also done

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman from Assam presented with fever and chills recurring every 48 hours. On examination, she was conscious, oriented, and febrile. CBC, LFT, and RFT were normal. Peripheral smear revealed the following. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing crescent-shaped gametocytes are suggestive of uncomplicated falciparum malaria. As this woman is from a North-Eastern state, the drug regimen of choice is ACT-AL (artemisinin combination therapy): 

  • Artemether (20mg)
  • Lumefantrine (120mg)  

This regimen is followed in the North-Eastern states of India due to documented resistance to sulphadoxine-pyrimethamine in these areas. ACT-AL is contraindicated in:

  • 1st trimester of pregnancy
  • Children < 5 kg

Related Pearl: Treatment of Malaria

 

Drug of Choice

 Primaquine Dose

P. vivax malaria

Chloroquine 25 mg/kg divided as:

10mg/kg on day 1

10mg/kg on day 2

5mg/kg on day 3

0.25 mg/kg for 14 days

P. falciparum malaria

North East

In other states

 

ACT-AL for 3 days

ACT-SP for 3 days 

 

0.75mg/kg on day 2

0.75mg/kg on day 2

Mixed infection

North East

In other states

ACT-AL for 3 days

ACT-SP for 3 days

 

0.25 mg/kg for 14 days

0.25 mg/kg for 14 days

Resistance to ACT/ Severe malaria

 

Quinine

 

-

Pregnancy

P. vivax

Chloroquine

Contraindicated

Pregnancy

P. falciparum

1st trimester: Quinine

2nd and 3rd trimester: Area specific ACT

 

Contraindicated

ACT: artemisinin-based combination therapy

AL: artemether-lumefantrine

SP: Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine

questions.text: A tourist who has been travelling in India presents with complaints of abdominal pain and multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. He reports having food at a local restaurant the previous night. Which of the following antidiarrheal agents is used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The antidiarrheal agent used in the given clinical scenario is loperamide. 

The given clinical scenario of a tourist with abdominal pain, and multiple episodes of diarrhea following food intake at an unhygienic place is suggestive of traveler’s diarrhea and the serotype of E.Coli most likely responsible for these symptoms would be Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). Enterotoxigenic E.Coli is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. 

Loperamide is an opioid receptor agonist and slows intestinal motility by direct effects on the circular and longitudinal muscles. It reduces fecal volume and increases viscosity. It is used in traveler's diarrhea for symptomatic treatment in conjunction with antibiotics. It is avoided in patients with dysentery. 

Other options: 

Option A: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog effective in treating severe secretory diarrhea that occurs due to hormone-secreting tumors in the GIT and pancreas. Its use is limited in traveler's diarrhea. 

Option C: Rifaximin is an antibiotic used in the treatment of traveler's diarrhea. It is an alternative to Azithromycin due to poor absorption. 

Option D: Bismuth subsalicylate is an over-the-counter (OTC) preparation used as an antidiarrheal agent. It is used in the treatment of traveler's diarrhea but is not preferred over loperamide due to a requirement for large doses, and salicylate toxicity, especially in high-risk groups (pregnancy, children, and individuals who take aspirin).

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for female with atrophic vaginitis with complains of itching?
questions.solution:
Atrophic vaginitis is treated with topical estrogen vaginal cream.

Use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally each day for 1 to 2 weeks generally provides relief. Systemic estrogen therapy should be considered to prevent recurrence of this disorder.

questions.text: A 7 year old child is noted to be extremely naughty, unable to sit in a place for a long time, excessively talking, and unable to concentrate on a thing for a long time. Which of the following drug is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD). The drug of choice for ADHD is Methylphenidate.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may sometimes disappear, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Note: Modafinil is used in the management of narcolepsy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of generalized weakness for 6 months. She has also had frequent headaches, mild fever and severe jaw pain. She does not complain of any vision abnormality.  She appears pale. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ESR. Peripheral smear shows normochromic anemia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient >50 years with fever, weakness, anemia, jaw claudication, and high ESR and CRP levels is suggestive of a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis.
The drug of choice is prednisone.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have temporal artery abnormalities such as enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and loss of pulse of the temporal artery, either unilateral or bilateral. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. 

GCA is very commonly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip. Mononeuropathies or peripheral neuropathies can also be seen. A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. Therefore treatment with oral steroids is given first and then a temporal artery biopsy is done for confirming the diagnosis. As the diagnosis may be done clinically, treatment is started immediately rather than delaying it after the biopsy.

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of the following is used to manage the symptoms in the initial stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
Finasteride is used for the management of urinary symptoms in the initial stages of Benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). 

Finasteride is a 5α-reductase enzyme inhibitor. 5α-reductase inhibitors inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. They are effective in the treatment of palpable enlarged prostate. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Conservative treatment is recommended for men with mild symptoms, flow rate >10ml/s, and good bladder emptying with residual urine <100ml. 

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. Tamsulosin is an adrenoreceptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

5α-reductase inhibitors are used if α-adrenergic blockers are not available, or not tolerated by the patient.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Hematuria
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis, hydroureter with renal functional impairment

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Laser ablative techniques using holmium YAG can also be done.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. His pulse rate is 55/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 50U/mL. Which of the following can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of organophosphate poisoning and IV atropine is the treatment of choice.

The organophosphates commonly used as pesticides are anticholinesterases. Toxicity occurs by excessive inhalation of vapors, ingestion, or percutaneous absorption. It inhibits the cholinesterase activity which results in an increase of acetylcholine, leading to cholinergic symptoms.

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

This may be followed by cognitive disturbances, convulsions, and neuromuscular blockade.

Treatment:

  • Maintenance of vital signs particularly respiration
  • Removal of clothing and washing of the skin
  • IV atropine 2- 5 mg. If IV administration is not possible, then 2 mg IM every 5-10 minutes (till muscarinic symptoms disappear)
  • Pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator can also be used for treatment

questions.text: Administering which of the following is the first step in the treatment of septic shock?
questions.solution:
Administering crystalloids is the first step in the treatment of septic shock.

Management of septic shock starts with evaluation and initial resuscitation by securing the airway (if indicated) and correcting hypoxemia and establishing venous access for the early administration of fluids and antibiotics.

Initial resuscitative therapy with aggressive administration of intravenous fluids (IVF), usually crystalloids are given at 30 mL/kg (actual body weight). Empirical antibiotic therapy started within the first hour.

Intravenous vasopressors are useful in patients who remain hypotensive despite adequate fluid resuscitation or who develop cardiogenic pulmonary oedema. Catecholamines are the vasopressors used most often, with norepinephrine being the first-line agent followed by epinephrine. Dobutamine therapy is recommended for patients with cardiac dysfunction.

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions as shown in the image below and later developed arthritis also.  What is the treatment of choice for a patient who presented with the following findings?
questions.solution:
The patient has right knee effusion, dactylitis of multiple digits, sharply demarcated red papulosquamous lesions on both knees all of which point towards a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

Methotrexate and apremilast are the first-line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

Features of psoriatic arthritis are :

  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis
  • associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or
  • dactylitis, enthesitis 
  • Inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints 
  • There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping.
  • Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the finger
  • Axial involvement may occur

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of DIP joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"
  • small joint ankylosis
  • Ray distribution of lesions

Note :

Indications for methotrexate (inflammatory conditions) include:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis 
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Polymyositis
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Giant cell arteritis 
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Other systemic vasculitis
  • Graft versus host disease associated with organ transplantation.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: The drug of choice for the treatment of infantile spasms is ________
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for infantile spasms is ACTH.

Infantile spasm (IS) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities). Their occurrence is almost entirely limited to infancy (the first year of life) and they are refractory to conventional anticonvulsant drugs.

West’s syndrome refers to the classic triad of infantile spasms, characteristic interictal EEG showing hypsarrhythmia, and neurodevelopmental regression.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presented with fever, lethargy and bruising. She was investigated thoroughly and was diagnosed to have acute lymphoid leukemia. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat her?
questions.solution:
L-asparaginase is used in the treatment of acute lymphoid leukaemia (ALL).

It is observed that some lymphoid malignancies are unable to synthesize asparagine on their own and must derive it from the bloodstream. L-asparaginase catalyses circulating L-asparagine, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis in the cancer cells.

Treatment of ALL

  • Induction: 4 weeks
    • L-asparaginase: single dose (side effects: pancreatitis, thrombosis)
    • Vincristine: weekly (side effects: neuropathy, SIADH)
    • Prednisolone
  • Consolidation: CNS prophylaxis 
    • Intrathecal methotrexate
  • Maintenance: 24-36 months
    • 6-Mercaptopurine
    • Methotrexate

Other options:

  • Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat acute myeloid leukaemia with t(9;22) BCR-ABL fusion gene.
  • Tretinoin is used in acute promyelocytic leukaemia with t(15;17) PML-RARA fusion gene.
  • Cladribine is used in hairy cell leukaemia.

questions.text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.solution:
The image shows inflammation and hypopyon. These signs, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery, suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis. The management is to administer intravitreal antibiotics.

The majority of patients with postoperative endophthalmitis present with an acute onset and within seven days after surgery.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation, which predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e., the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber.

The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid, and decrease in vision.

The patient classically presents with inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and a hypopyon, due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

Intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis. 

Other treatments:

  • Topical antibiotic
  • Cycloplegia
  • Oral steroids
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: A young male presents with reduced sleep, hyperactivity, and elevated mood. He has a history of depression from 4 years back. Which of the following drug should be used for long-term treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of depression, with the current symptoms of mania suggests bipolar disorder. Lithium is a mood stabilizer that is used in the treatment of acute mania and bipolar disorder.

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index and hence frequent monitoring of serum lithium concentration is necessary for patients who are on lithium therapy.

0.5-0.8 mEq/L is considered ideal for maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder whereas a serum lithium concentration of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L is required in patients with episodes of acute mania.

Initially, lithium toxicity presents with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, mild diarrhea, and fine tremors. Nervous system toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, ataxia, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
This is a case of nodular acne. This comes under Grade IV acne.

Oral Isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne (nodular, acne conglobata)

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia was brought to the hospital with acute onset of neck stiffness. On examination, his upper body and neck are rigid. On review of his medications, it is seen that he was started on haloperidol 5 days back. Which of the following drugs​ can be used to treat his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the history of recent haloperidol usage the most probable diagnosis is acute dystonia.  Treatment for this condition includes anticholinergics, such as benztropine, diphenhydramine, or trihexyphenidyl.

Classification of antipsychotic drugs:

Generation D2 receptor 5HT2A antagonism Pathways Drugs
First (Typical) Preferred Low  All of them- mesocortical, mesolimbic, nigrostriatal, tuberoinfundibular, and CTZ

Haloperidol, Fluphenazine, Chlorpromazine,

Thioridazine (least D2 blocking among typical, markedly anticholinergic)
Second (Atypical) Selective

High 

 

 Mostly mesolimbic and mesocortical

Risperidone, Sertindole, Aripiprazole, Quetiapine, Clozapine
